indicators.justification:
Emission data is mainly available on the air quality portal created by the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia(1). The latest dataset was published in 2019, however, it only covers data from 2007 to 2017(2). The dataset is given in XML format and provides data disaggregated by sectors. More granular data can be found on an interactive map that provides information on each individual source of emission(3). The National Statistics Office (Geostat) also provides various categories of environmental data(4), however, it is not disaggregated at the level of the air quality portal. Furthermore, the website of The Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture provides daily reports on air quality monitoring.(5)

Sources:
(1):https://air.gov.ge/
(2):https://air.gov.ge/en/pages/10/10
(3):http://map.emoe.gov.ge/#
(4):https://www.geostat.ge/en/modules/categories/565/environmental-indicators
(5):https://mepa.gov.ge/Ge/TheQualityofAirPollution/

indicators.justification:
A national red list is available in the form of an annex to a Government decree(1), it provides a categorization in accordance with IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, Version 3.1, 2001, however it is does not conform to open data standards and is updated once every 10 years. according to Article 5 of the law of Georgia on the "Red Book" and the "Red List".(2)

Water quality data can be found on a website created by the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture(1). It also contains a section for water quantity data but it seems to be unavailable due to a technical issue(2). various categories of data are also available on the website of the National Statistics Office, such as consumption of ozone-depleting substances, emissions of pollutants, greenhouse gas emissions, household water use, etc.(3)

indicators.justification:
Beneficial ownership as a concept is only applied to broadcasters (as well as the financial sector, however, no data is published , and the Communication Commission maintains a corresponding registry(1), which contains a list of all broadcasters and provides names, last names, ID numbers, amount of shares held, and other information about the beneficial owners of broadcasters.

Civil society organizations in Georgia, including the Institute for Development of Freedom of Information (IDFI), urged the Georgian Government to create a beneficial ownership registry that could collect the information of the ultimate owners of companies, most importantly in the sphere of extractive industries. However, the Georgian Government has not yet pursued any ambitious agenda regarding this area (2)(3).

Sources:
(1):https://registry.comcom.ge/Organisation.aspx?OrgID=2
(2):https://idfi.ge/public/upload/Article/Beneficial-Ownership_ENG_29_01_2021.pdf 
(3):https://www.transparency.ge/en/blog/transparency-international-georgias-proposals-georgias-national-anticorruption-strategy-and

indicators.justification:
Company information is available as structured open data at the National Statistics Office's website(1). The data is gathered from the public registry's portal that is used to search registration documents and other decision-making documents of individual entrepreneurs, commercial legal entities, non-profit legal entities, etc(2), however, it only allows for single searches. Additionally, there is an interactive map tool available, that allows users to view companies according to their locations and other relevant data(3).

indicators.justification:
CRVS data is available through the National Statistics Office(1). The office uses ICD 10 and provides complete datasets on mortality data. However, the birth data is missing some key indicators such as the usual residence of mothers, their ethnicity, intervals between births, gestation periods, etc...

indicators.justification:
No such real-time data is being produced. However, the national Covid-19 Prevention Platform provides real-time data on the number of Covid Patients under hospital supervision(1). Furthermore, the National Statistics Office provides data on the total quantity of hospital beds in the country(2). Using these two numbers, media outlets often estimate the current capacity of the healthcare system.

Sources:
(1):https://stopcov.ge/en
(2):https://www.geostat.ge/en/modules/categories/54/healthcare

indicators.justification:
The National Center for Disease Control provides a statistics section on their specialized website dedicated to the vaccination process(1). The data is presented in the form of infogram graphs and interactive maps, but bulk data and machine-readable datasets are not available. Furthermore, the data is missing several key indicators and is highly aggregated.

Sources:
(1):https://vaccines.ncdc.ge/statistics/

indicators.justification:
The land use information is provided by the National Agency of Public Registry(1). Individual records can be accessed through a search function(2). as well as an e-map portal. Land parcels can be searched by indicating their cadaster code, name of the owner, or address. Furthermore, the map also highlights forested and protected areas in green, which can be clicked on to receive additional data. Bulk data is behind a paywall and requires registration and payment of a fee for access. Once accessed, it is provided in "shp" format(4).

Sources:
(1):https://napr.gov.ge/
(2):https://naprweb.reestri.gov.ge/#/search
(3):http://maps.napr.gov.ge/#zoom=7&lat=42.13099&lon=43.9915&layers=B0000000FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFT0000F
(4):https://napr.gov.ge/p/605

indicators.justification:
Georgia did not have a systemic land cadaster registry prior to 2006. Therefore, some land tenure data registered before 2006 is not digitized(1). However, a significant portion is available and can be accessed through an e-portal(2). individual records are linked to official registration documents, but datasets in bulk are not available and API access is not provided.

Sources:
(1):https://napr.gov.ge/p/595
(2):http://maps.napr.gov.ge/#zoom=8&lat=42.13099&lon=43.9915&layers=B0000000FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFT0000F

indicators.justification:
Most of the Budget data is accessible through the website of the Ministry of Finance(1), however, it is highly aggregated. Within the framework of the OGP Georgia Action Plan 2016-2017, the State Audit Office developed an analytical platform "Budget Monitor"(2), by means of which the wide public can access information about the state budget, public resources management issues, audit findings, issued recommendations and the state of their implementation(3). While The data is quite comprehensive, it is usually updated quite a bit late than the publication of documents by the Ministry of Finance. Even though Georgia has been scoring fairly high in international rankings in areas such as budget transparency(4), challenges remain in terms of openness. There is still no way to access data in bulk, and the most common formats that are being used to publish, are not ideal for data analysis.

Sources:
(1):https://www.mof.ge/en/4545
(2):https://budgetmonitor.ge/en
(3):https://ogpgeorgia.gov.ge/upload/pages/24/OGP%20Georgia%20Action%20Plan%20for%202018-2019.pdf
(4):https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/georgia

indicators.justification:
The Declarations are available on an e-portal maintained by the Civil Service Bureau(1). The data is updated regularly and documents are available dating back to 1998. However, declarations are uploaded in PDF format, which is not ideal for data analysis and processing, and the search function does not support searching by names of family members. Additionally, bulk download is not available. 


Sources:
(1):https://declaration.gov.ge/

indicators.justification:
In 2011, the Legislative Amendments to the Law of Georgia on Political Associations of Citizens entered into force. Within the mandate granted by law, the State Audit Office works with all political parties to collect and publish data regarding donations, spending and other activities on the agency's online portal(2).
The data cannot be accessed and downloaded as a whole, the official portal only allows the download of a single page of entries. However, a local Transparency Georgia a local NGO has created a portal based on the official data, that provides the option for bulk download at the bottom of the page(3).

Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/28324?publication=32
(2):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/28324?publication=32
(3):https://www.transparency.ge/politicaldonations/

indicators.justification:
The data is submitted annually in the form of reports to the parliament of Georgia, this year it was published on their website(1), however, no trace of previously published data is evident. The data is provided as pdf files in an unstructured form. According to a review conducted by IDFI, along with some other inconsistencies, the published data is missing a number of public bodies and various public bodies have not indicated the normative acts based on which they refused disclosure of public information(2).

Sources:

indicators.justification:
The main point of access for public procurement data is the Unified electronic system of State Procurement/Georgian electronic Government Procurement (GeGP), launched in 2010, a portal managed by LEPL State Procurement Agency(1). The website provides comprehensive information about all procurement activities and the contract implementation stages.  The portal aligns with the Open Contracting Data Standards to some degree, however, it does not provide an analytical tool, nor the possibility to download data in bulk. For this purpose, the State Procurement Agency, in cooperation with OGP, World Bank, and Open Contracting Partnership, developed a modern portal(2) that meets all open data standards, provides machine-readable data, open licensing, OCDS standards, API access, and data is open formats (JSON, XLSX). However, this portal has been seemingly abandoned, since the data on it has not been updated since 2019, and there are some outstanding technical issues with the website itself. An alternative portal was created by Transparency Georgia(3), which provides users with analytical tools and allows them to view detailed supplier profiles, procurer profiles, aggregate analysis. The data on this website comes from the  State Procurement Agency's online procurement platform, through an auxiliary program attached to this website which automatically downloads and parses the data.

Sources:
(1):https://tenders.procurement.gov.ge/login.php
(2):https://odapi.spa.ge/#/tenders
(3):https://www.tendermonitor.ge/

indicators.justification:
There is some evidence of the government supporting and encouraging data reuse, mostly through hackathons(1) and data competitions(2) organized by the National Statistics Office (Geostat) and Georgia's Innovation and Technology Agency (GITA). There is no activity on the government-run open data portal(3), and no relevant news in the news feed of the public registry(4). Furthermore, there are some NGOs that conduct activities in this direction. For example, IDFI's analytical article contests(5)(6), which instructs participants to use data from datalab(7), IDFI's own open data portal.

indicators.justification:
The most prominent Open Government Data initiative in Georgia is the Open Government Partnership. Georgia has been a member since 2011(1) and has developed 4 action plans since then(2). The Government of Georgia and the Data Exchange Agency(now called The Digital Government Agency) are the main bodies in charge of implementation. The latter has a set budget(3) approved by law. There is no evidence of any guidance or support for the Government in publishing open data (apart from isolated activities from a few CSOs such as IDFI)(4). There is no evidence of any senior politician lobbying and advocating for open data. The OGP initiative covers some national agencies such as the Public Procurement Agency and Public Service Hall, as well as activities in various municipalities(5), selectively.

Sources:
(1):https://www.opengovpartnership.org/members/georgia/
(2):https://ogpgeorgia.gov.ge/en/monitoring-and-evaluation/

There is few evidence of the government providing training to develop civil servants' data literacy and data skills. Mainly the annual reports of the State Inspector's Service(1), which contains information about various types of training activities conducted by the agency. There is no evidence of a planned and sustainable strategy in this regard.

indicators.justification:
Beneficial ownership as a concept is only applied to broadcasters and the financial sector. The Communication Commission maintains a corresponding registry(1), however, no such data is published for the financial sector.

Civil society organizations in Georgia, including the Institute for Development of Freedom of Information (IDFI), urged the Georgian Government to create a general beneficial ownership registry that could collect the information of the ultimate owners of companies, most importantly in the sphere of extractive industries. However, the Georgian Government has not yet pursued any ambitious agenda regarding this area (2)(3).

(1):https://registry.comcom.ge/Organisation.aspx?OrgID=2

(3):https://www.transparency.ge/en/blog/transparency-international-georgias-proposals-georgias-national-anticorruption-strategy-and

indicators.justification:
The main normative act regulating the matters of accessibility and PWDS, is the Law of Georgia on the rights of persons with disabilities(1). even though it does not directly mention public data accessibility and collection, it can be assumed that the law applies broadly to the responsibility of public bodies to services provide accessibly. However, there are very few examples in practice where formal accessibility standards are implemented, one of such examples is the website of the parliament of Georgia(2), which has implemented WGAC 2.0 optimization. The OGP action plans provide further recommendations for implementing accessibility standards at the central as well as municipal levels.

Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/4923984?publication=0
(2):https://parliament.ge/

indicators.justification:
The Law of Georgia on Personal Data Protection was enacted in 2011 and the latest revision dates back to 2019 (1). The law asserts that data processing shall be admissible if there is a data subject's consent; Article 15 of the law guarantees the data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves. Article 4 lays out the main - principles for data processing. Chapter 6 and 7 of the law on data protection outline the main areas of activity of the Personal Data Protection Inspector and the measures applied by the Inspector for the enforcement of law;
State Inspector's Service is an independent state authority that, as a legal successor of the Office of the Personal Data Protection Inspector, operates in Georgia since May 2019(2). The national framework does not address algorithmic decision-making and location data, nor does it obligate data-controllers and data-processors to notify any appropriate authorities. The Law on Personal Data Protection applies to the entire territory of Georgia and to public agencies as well as natural or legal persons, as inferred from the definitions provided by the framework. Furthermore, Georgia has been moving towards implementing and enforcing the GDPR(3), but this process is at a very early stage for the time being.


Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/1561437?publication=9
(2): https://personaldata.ge/en 
(3): https://personaldata.ge/en/press/post/6464

The official language recognized in Georgia is the Georgian language, and the official languages in the autonomous region of Abkhazia are the Georgian and Abkhaz languages. indicators.justification:
An Open Data Portal(1) was created in 2014, however, publishing on the portal is not mandatory and is at the discretion of individual public agencies. The only mention of "Open Data" in Georgian legislation is found in the LAW OF GEORGIA ON THE LEGAL ENTITY UNDER PUBLIC LAW CALLED THE DIGITAL GOVERNANCE AGENCY (2), which provides very broad definitions. The main Frameworks concerning this issue are the OGP action plans(3), which lack the full force of law and therefore, cannot mandate any of the open data related requirements.

Sources:
(1):https://data.gov.ge/
(2):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/4893222?publication=0
(3):https://www.opengovpartnership.org/members/georgia/

The electronic system of asset declarations of officials has been operating in Georgia since 2010, the main framework in this field is "the Law on Conflict of Interest and Corruption in Public Service"(1). More specific instructions and details are provided in the "Technical instruction on filling the asset declaration of a public official provides forms for the collection of data"(3).

indicators.justification:
A framework exists for regulating lobbying activities(1), however, it does not include any obligation for publishing the collected data. Georgian law defines lobbying as any influence not prohibited by law of a person registered as a lobbyist on a representative or an executive body for the purpose of achieving legislative change. Any capable citizen of Georgia may register as a lobbyist, with some exceptions, including when the citizen's work position is incompatible with conducting lobbying activities or when a citizen has been convicted for a crime against the state or official misconduct(2). The publication of the registry is outlined in the OGP action plan(3).

Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/ka/document/view/13552?publication=7
(2):https://www.transparency.ge/en/post/report/implementing-georgia-s-anti-corruption-laws-practice-remains-problem
(3):https://info.parliament.ge/file/1/BillReviewContent/243050

evidence.title: Implementing Georgia’s Anti-Corruption Laws in Practice Remains a Problem
Report of the Parliament on the activities conducted within the scope of OGP

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the lobbying framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Political parties operating in Georgia are obligated to disclose received donations to the State Audit Service, this is regulated by the Law of Georgia on Political Associations of Citizens(1). Furthermore, "the Decree of the General Auditor on regulating issues related to the transparency of political finances" regulates the formal details of collection and publication of data(2). Lastly, definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties can be found in the Election Code of Georgia(3).

Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/28324?publication=32
(2):https://monitoring.sao.ge/files/8/brzanreba2020_09_14.pdf
(3):https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/1557168?publication=65

evidence.title: Law of Georgia on Political Associations of Citizens
Decree of the General Auditor on regulating issues related to the transparency of political finances

The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework requires the public disclosure of the identity of every donor.

The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.

How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Ministries and regulatory agencies solicit comments on proposed regulations from the general public, through public meetings, targeted outreach to stakeholders, such as business associations or other groups, through email. There currently is no regulatory framework that mandates the publication of this data(1) in place, however, Georgia has joined initiatives to implement such regulations officially(2). Furthermore, decree No 135 mentioned in the World Bank's source (3) mandated the publication of draft laws and changes to existing laws but only for a limited set of laws and regulations, however, the decree is no longer in force since 2018.

Sources:
(1):https://rulemaking.worldbank.org/en/data/explorecountries/georgia#
(2):https://www.ogp.gov.ge/en/consultation/
(3):https://matsne.gov.ge/ka/document/view/2239961?publication=2

evidence.title: The World Bank's Public Consultation in Rulemaking Database

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Public institutions are obliged to submit to the Parliament of Georgia, the President of Georgia, and the Prime Minister of Georgia, a report on the number of applications received for issuing public information. This is mandated by the General Administrative Code of Georgia(1). Additionally, the report is published on the website of the Legislative Herald of Georgia(2), however, the data is unstructured and often contains inconsistencies due to the fact that there is no official monitoring and verification process in place.(3) The public defender's latest report states the following "Closing public information on the ground of personal data protection and neglecting the public interest were challenges encountered by representatives of the media and human rights defenders in 2020. The Georgian law on freedom of information is flawed and needs to be fundamentally reformed, which began almost eight years ago and has not yet been completed. In addition, it is important for the country to ratify the Council of Europe Convention on Access to Official Documents of 18 June 2009, which Georgia signed as soon as the Convention was adopted"(4).

Sources:
(1)https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/16270?publication=33
(2):https://matsne.gov.ge/en
(3):https://idfi.ge/ge/results-of-monitoring-the-accuracy-of-the-december-10th-reports-from-public-institutions
(4):https://www.ombudsman.ge/eng/akhali-ambebi/sakartvelis-sakhalkho-damtsvelis-saparlamento-angarishi-2020

evidence.title: THE GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE CODE OF GEORGIA
Results of Monitoring The Accuracy of the December 10th Reports from Public Institutions

indicators.justification:
There is little evidence online of products or services using company data to support due diligence. The most popular use case of the company info portal is the website developed by local NGO Transparency Georgia called CompanyInfo(1), it is being used by journalists to research analytical articles and reports(2)(3).

(1):https://www.companyinfo.ge/en

indicators.justification:
Since the datasets are not available as open data, it is not very practical to use them as an analytical tool. There are isolated examples of journalists using the portal to track the real estate of politicians and public officials(1), but other resources can be used to achieve this goal more effectively, such as the declaration portal. (2)

Sources:
(1):https://rustavi2.ge/ka/news/116029
(2):https://declaration.gov.ge/

indicators.justification:
CSOs regularly use data on political finances, public officials' asset declarations, and the performance of RTI processes to produce various types of studies and reports. Due to the absence of open datasets and analytical tools, this kind of data processing can be too time-consuming for fast-paced media outlets, for this reason, they mostly cover the studies and reports published by CSOs based on political finance data and public officials' asset declarations. One major breakthrough in this regard was the implementation of Decree #81(1), a monitoring mechanism for faulty or inaccurate asset declarations. The Institute for Development of Freedom of Information (IDFI), together with other civil society organizations, was involved in the elaboration process of the decree(2).

Sources:
(1):https://matsne.gov.ge/ka/document/view/3578912?publication=0
(2)https://idfi.ge/en/new_system_property_declaration_idfi_evaluation?fbclid=IwAR3CfDE7OSeTJlU7EomOy7R1qzmYiI6YbaZkoasgOv07lcSN_5io1O9YcFY

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of multiple different uses involving different organisations, mostly NGOs, think tanks, and Media outlets(1)(2)(3)(4). The best example of government procurement data being presented through a data-driven dashboard is Transparency Georgia's monitoring portal(5). This tool is also regularly used by think tanks, NGOs, and media to analyze and monitor Procurement data, uncovering cases of suspected corruption, nepotism, and wasteful practices, which in turn contributes to increased transparency and accountability in the public sector(6)(7)(8)(9).

Sources:
(1):https://idfi.ge/en/the_covid-19_related_state_procurements_
(2):https://transparency.ge/en/post/public-procurement-during-state-emergency-basic-data-analysis-and-corruption-risks
(3):http://www.bridge.org.ge/ka/%E1%83%9E%E1%83%A3%E1%83%91%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98%E1%83%99%E1%83%90%E1%83%AA%E1%83%98%E1%83%94%E1%83%91%E1%83%98/research/2017-09-12-sursatis-sajaro-shesyidvebis-sistemis
(4):http://geoeconomics.ge/?p=7118
(5):https://www.tendermonitor.ge/
(6):https://www.transparency.ge/en/blog/suspicious-procurements-chkhorotsku-municipality
(7):https://rustavi2.ge/ka/news/189111
(8):https://tabula.ge/ge/news/670277-gharibashviltan-dakavshirebul-kompanias
(9):https://1tv.ge/news/idfi-shi-ackhadeben-rom-saqartvelos-sagareo-saqmeta-saministrom-saechvo-shesyidvebi-ganakhorciela/
